Where is the X?
Look at the X, X’, ‘Find the X, X’, and ‘Where is the X, X’
Notes: No significant difference between monolingual and bilingual. All the effects are caused by the trilinguals not showing ME. Surprising differences in vocabulary, with trilinguals having an English productive vocabulary twice as large as that of bilinguals. BH&W used one-tailed tests to show that children were above chance in the FF trials. Participants are still not reliably looking at the novel object after hearing a novel word, but they are decreasing their tendency to look at the familiar object instead. W&BH use difference scores between baseline and poslabeling windows, and not absolute looking time after labeling against chance level as their DV. Eleven additional infants were rejected. r_vocab: B=−.048, average for monolingual, bilingual, and trilingual. No correlation presented separately for each language group. BUT: can't calculate r because don't have SD for CDI

question: This is a Y. Can you show me the X
Notes: The authors introduce 3 different age groups, 2, 3, and 4-year olds. But they do not present the statistics separately for children in each of the 3 different age groups, only ANOVAs comparing the groups. Also, they had only one disambiguation trial per condition, and tested 4 conditions per child, which is crazy!!!  I also don't know what to do with the trials with facts. I would probably just use the word/word trials, but even then, I am not sure how you would incorporate x2 into your analyses.

question:
‘My cat stepped on this. Can
you show me the nixon ?
This is a X. Can you show me the thing my uncle gave me
This fell in the sink. Can you show me the thing that goes in my desk ?
Can you help me find the X? Which one is the X?
Notes: The authors do not present statistics for the NS trials. But they report that 56% of children selected the target over the distractor (2 out of 2), with 44% of children selecting the target either 1 out of 2 or 0 out of 2. From these numbers we might be able to compute some statistics. Note that they had only 2 trials with 2AFC for each child in a NN paradigm.
